Author: palish
Content: I wish Hacker News allowed us to upvote or downvote individual paragraphs.  I upvoted you because of your first paragraph, but would have downvoted otherwise.  (Shareholders besides the management team still matter. :P)

Author: trezor
Content:
I use Windows and I'll use the Adobe PDF plugin any day.

From Adobe Acrobat 5 to 6 the changes were truly horrible, and the reader became bloated as heck, which made me stay at Acrobat 5 for quite a while since Acrobat 6 seemed to offer no real added value while pretty much every PDF on the internet worked in Adobe Reader 5.

Since version 7 though it seems like they got back on the right track, and I honestly don't get what people are bitching about.

Author: trezor
Content:
So he doesn't like its usability, he doesn't have to use it.

Scribd requires you to sign up for an account to access the original document, basically requiring you to sign up for their "service" when it is beyond obvious that the one thing you want is to avoid it.

I call major BS on that.

Author: cousin_it
Content:
If I build a house there is more value in the world, so there should be more paper money too - without affecting inflation. This is what happens with fiat money.

Depending on what other goods were spent to build the house, the total value in the world could increase or decrease. Does your system burn some paper money to reflect that?

Author: gaius
Content:
That is true, but the volume of useful work that can be done on a computer doesn't decrease; the slowness is almost always in the user interface portion, not the computation.

Obviously this is different in fields were people actually are constrained by their processors and staying on the cutting edge is a competitive advantage. We have a couple of apps like that (e.g. Monte Carlo simulations where we can basically eat as much power as we can get) but for most people (including me), most of the time, computers became "good enough" for work on the desktop 10-15 years ago.

Author: Maktab
Content:
That's not really correct. There's still no word on whether he'll be allowed to send and receive emails directly during his term(s) as president. The chances are that the risks will be considered too high to permit it.

If that happens, he'll be in the same position as George W. Bush, who was a fairly prolific emailer before becoming president but was not permitted to use the technology directly while in office.

As an aside, it may not always be a good thing. South Africa's former president Thabo Mbeki was quite well known for having a computer at his desk and a personal email account while in office. Unfortunately, he tended to use his to research crank AIDS activists online, write raving and offensive weekly newsletters on his party's official website and send off diplomatically-unsound emails to newspapers, unpopular researchers and other world leaders. Perhaps it is better to keep a president isolated to some extent.

Author: palish
Content: The automobile was invented by a German, but it was popularized by Henry Ford. Also, consider that if that German hadn't invented the automobile, Ford still would have. i.e. Ford wasn't inspired by that German, because he was already working on an automobile. His autobiography is very good: http://www.gutenberg.org/dirs/etext05/hnfrd10.txt

Author: palish
Content:
How can content be "locked away" inside any digital non-DRM format? The purpose of a format is to represent content, and that's what PDF/DOC does.

Also, in regards to your other point, I find Dropbox's "copy public link" mechanism to be a far easier way to share content than to upload it to any website (not just scribd), because I don't have to use a browser in the first place. The content is already uploaded and ready to be shared.

Author: rbanffy
Content:
I have a very interesting story about exactly this situation, but I am forbidden by regulations to share it here. ;-)

But the reply alongside mine nails it quite well - the HR staff has no authority to bump you up. You earn what they pay for that position and that's all the HR people can do.

Author: gaius
Content: I'm not sure it makes sense to use FreeBSD on the desktop. Not that it isn't perfectly capable mind, but if you want a BSD desktop or laptop there's OSX. I've FreeBSD running in a VirtualBox VM; best of all possible worlds.

Author: rbanffy
Content:
Let me rephrase your question:

"What's wrong with, say, Psychology, that makes so few men enroll?" or "Why there are so few men graduating from fashion schools?"

I agree that looking at the whole picture explains it better than looking at a very small part of it and wondering, "if 50% of this picture is mostly green, why all I see is blue?". The answer could be simple: maybe you are looking at the sky.

When I graduated in a, say, 50 people class, 4 of them were women. Apart from the fact that we went to separate toilets, there was not much of a difference.

Author: mjnaus
Content: Yep, unfortunately addressing key issues won't make any president popular with the ruling elite in the U.S. And since those are the ones providing most of the campaigning funds for presidential candidates, guess who Obama will be loyal to... If only Ron Paul would have made it...

Author: gaius
Content: 500x is a figure I'm deeply suspicious of. Average worker in the entire economy vs CEO of a Fortune 100, maybe. The "average" CEO is just the owner of a small company and probably makes <5x more than even their lowest paid worker.
